hawaiian_text: 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ua 'ike au, he kanaka nui nō 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, a ua hele aku nei ma Ko'olau, a 'o wau he inoa nona." 'Ī mai lākou: "'A'ole, 'o 'oe nō, pela ko makou lohe, no laila, e make ana 'oe iā mākou, 'a'ole 'oe e ola." 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ho'i aku ho'i hā kākou i lalo e hakakā ai." A hiki lākou i lalo, e hao aku ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, pau loa i ka make, a koe aku ho'okahi kanaka, 'o ia ka i holo aku ā loa'a 'o 'Ama'u ma Waikīkī, 'ōlelo akula ia i ka make o lākou a pau loa, a koe ia i 'āha'ilono e lohe ai 'o 'Ama'u.
deepseek-v3-0324-dsapi_translation: Nāmakaokapāoʻo said: "I have seen that Nāmakaokapāoʻo is indeed a great man, and he has gone to Koʻolau, and I am a name for him." They replied: "No, it is you, so we have heard, therefore, you will die by our hands, you will not live." Nāmakaokapāoʻo said: "Then let us all go down and fight." When they went down, Nāmakaokapāoʻo attacked, and all were slain except for one man, who fled and found ʻAmaʻu at Waikīkī. He told of the death of all of them, leaving only him to carry the news so that ʻAmaʻu might hear."
deepseek-v3-0324-dsapi_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>  
Nāmakaokapāoʻo said: "I have seen that Nāmakaokapāoʻo is indeed a great man, and he has gone to Koʻolau, and I am a name for him." They replied: "No, it is you, so we have heard, therefore, you will die by our hands, you will not live." Nāmakaokapāoʻo said: "Then let us all go down and fight." When they went down, Nāmakaokapāoʻo attacked, and all were slain except for one man, who fled and found ʻAmaʻu at Waikīkī. He told of the death of all of them, leaving only him to carry the news so that ʻAmaʻu might hear."  
</translation>  

<commentary>  
This passage is part of a larger Hawaiian narrative, likely from a historical or legendary account, depicting a confrontation involving the warrior Nāmakaokapāoʻo. The exchange highlights themes of identity, bravery, and the transmission of news (ʻāhaʻilono) in Hawaiian oral tradition. Such passages often serve to preserve genealogical or heroic deeds within the cultural memory.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I know. Nāmakaokapāo'o is a really big guy. He went to Ko'olau. I'm named after him." The soldiers said, "No, it's you. That's what we heard. So, we're going to kill you. You won't survive." Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "Well, let's go down and fight." When they got down, Nāmakaokapāo'o went to work and killed them all except one man, who ran off and reached 'Ama'u in Waikīkī. He told him about the how they were all killed except for one runner to go and tell 'Ama'u about it.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
